questiontext.text: The template for PCR is:

answer.text: RNA
single stranded DNA
double stranded DNA
mRNA
All of the above

questiontext.text: The insertion of a cloning plasmid into competent bacterial cells typically involves one of the following process:

answer.text: Transduction
Polymerase Chain Reaction
Conjugation
Transformation
Hybridization

questiontext.text:
You design the following reverse primer:

ACTGATTAGGTCAACGTC

What is the primers melting temperature (Tm)?

answer.text: 52°C
48°C
56°C
50°C
58°C

questiontext.text: You digest a 5 kb plasmid with EcoRI + XbaI. Below is the restriction map of that digest. What bands would expect to see after the digest is run on an agarose gel?

answer.text: 1.5 kb and 1 kb
3 kb and 1 kb
1.5 kb, 1 kb and 0.5 kb
1 kb and 0.5 kb
1 kb

questiontext.text: You use a BLAST search to find similarities between?

answer.text: nucleotides
mRNA
proteins
all of the above

questiontext.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding degeneracy?

answer.text: Degeneracy means quite different DNA can be transcribed and translated into similar proteins
The degeneracy of a protein sequence is determined by the number of possible codons for the amino acids in a particular sequence
There is a codon preference which is unique to every species
There are 5 possible codons for the amino acid Serine
There is only one codon for the amino acid Methionine

questiontext.text: You perform a BLAST search and one of the fields in the results gives an E-value. What is an E-value?

answer.text: An E-value stands for Expectation value. The E-value determines the probability for a homologous alignment to have occurred by chance. The smaller the E-value the less likely an alignment has occurred by chance.

An E-value stands for Endogenous value. It estimates the likelihood that the sequence match comes from within the same species as the query search. The smaller the E-value the more related the aligned sequence is.
An E-value stands for Exclusion value. It determines to what degree results should be excluded because of inaccuracies, lower Exclusion values are preferred.
An E-value stands for Emergent-value. If the Emergent value is high then it is more likely that the aligned sequence is from a new species.
none of the above

questiontext.text: You are cloning a 500 bp fragment of your gene of interest in to pBluescript. You are using blue/white screening and antibiotic selection. You come to analyse your plates after 24 hours at 37°C. All of the colonies are blue. What can you deduce?

answer.text: The transformation worked
It may be that the ligation reaction did not work
Perhaps the plasmid you used to clone in your insert was incompletely digested or not digested at all prior to insertion of your fragment of interest
You should use controls in the future. Repeat the restriction digests of your insert and plasmid and perform the ligation and transformation once more, this time use controls.
all of the above

questiontext.text: You plate transformants on L-agar plates with 50 µg/ml Ampicillin, 0.1 mM IPTG, and 40 µg/ml XGal. What is IPTG?

answer.text: IPTG is a substrate in the reaction which results in the colonies turning indigo blue

IPTG is an inducer of the lac operon. It is widely used in molecular biology to regulate gene expression, in this experiment it turns on the transcription of the ampicillin resistance gene - the product of which is β lactamase

IPTG is an inducer of the lac operon. It mimics the natural inducer of the lac operon allolactose but unlike allolactose, IPTG is not degraded by β galactosidase - the protein product of lacZ. This means that IPTG is not turned over and levels remain constant. In blue/white screening IPTG switches on lacZ, β galactosidase is then produced which converts XGal into a blue coloured molecule which makes the colonies blue
IPTG is a special enhancer of antibiotic resistance which works especially well with the lactamase family of antibiotics

questiontext.text: At which cycle in the PCR do you first see the final product?
Select the correct statement below concerning the differences between PCR and the Sanger sequencing method.

answer.text: 3 primers are used in the Sanger method; only 2 primers are used in PCR
PCR uses dNTPs. In the Sanger method 1:100 ddNTPs : dNTPs are used
The Sanger method can be used to copy mRNA as well as DNA. PCR can only copy DNA
Because of the use of ddNTPs, the extension step in the Sanger method is at least twice as long as in PCR
All of the above

questiontext.text: PCR can be used to:

answer.text: diagnose genetic diseases
solve crimes
study gene function
detect viruses or bacteria
do all of the above

questiontext.text: Real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) can be used for:

answer.text: gene expression analysis
determination of viral load
detection of viral genetically modified organisms GMOs
SNP genotyping
all of the above

questiontext.text: In real-time qPCR, a dye called SYBR makes the DNA fluorescent. How does SYBR achieve this?

answer.text: SYBR forms hydrogen bonds with Gs and Cs
SYBR bind specifically to As and Ts in the DNA
SYBR is a large molecule which displaces one strand of DNA forming strong hydrogen bonds with the other strand
SYBR intercalates the DNA helix

questiontext.text: What is the threshold cycle (Ct) in real-time qPCR?

answer.text: The number of PCR cycles required for the fluorescent signal generated by SYBR to exceed the level of background fluorescence.
The number of PCR cycles taken for 200 fluorescence units to be recorded
The number of PCR cycles taken for the product levels to tail off
The number of PCR cycles taken for 1000 fluorescence units to be recorded

questiontext.text: In the plasmid purification protocol, bacterial cells are lysed, after this you are instructed to handle the resulting viscous solution with care. Why is this?

answer.text: It is possible that the protein will engulf your plasmid DNA, thereby lowering yields
Plasmid DNA is at its most sensitive post cell lysis, if you are not gentle it will break and you will not be able to store/use it
Chromosomal DNA is sensitive and could 'shear off' to form smaller DNA which may be co-purified with plasmid DNA if it is of similar size
If you are not gentle host cell factors such as endogenous restriction enzymes will attack the plasmid DNA
all of the above

questiontext.text: If the DNA stock solution is 2 mg/ml and you need 1 µg/µl in the reaction how much of the stock solution would you need to add to a 20 µl?

answer.text: 0.1 ml
15 µl
1.5 µl

questiontext.text: The stock concentration of forward and reverse primers are 0.01 µM. The required concentration of primers for PCR reaction is 0.5 nM. What volume of each primer must be added to the PCR tubes, if 0.05 ml of PCR reaction is set up.

answer.text: 2 µl
5 µl
2.5 µl
10 µl

questiontext.text: You have a 20X TBE buffer. To run a gel, you need 0.5 litres of a 2X solution of TBE. What volume will be added from the 20X stock solution to get the required 2X concentration?

answer.text: 10 ml
20 ml
100 ml
50 ml
0.001 litres

questiontext.text: You are required to carry out a restriction digest using BamHI and KpnI enzymes. A 30 µl digest is set up and 1 µl of both enzymes are added.The concentration of the buffer is 20X and for the digest 1X concentration of buffer is required. The concentration of DNA is 2 mg/ml and 1.5 µg of DNA is required. What volume of DNA and restriction buffer must be added to carry out this restriction digest?

answer.text: 1.5 µl of buffer and 0.75 µl of DNA
1.5 µl of buffer and 1 µl of DNA
2 µl of buffer and 0.75 µl of DNA
1.5 µl of buffer and 2 µl of DNA
1.5 µl of buffer and 1.5 µl of DNA

questiontext.text:
Deduce forward and reverse primers using the sequence given below and incorporate BamHI restriction site in the forward and KpnI in the reverse primers. Remember to include the stiffener region.

BamHI recognition sequence is GGATCC

KpnI recognition sequence is   GGTACC

 

ATGGCATATAGAGCAGTACATGAGTTTATACTAGCTATGAA

TTACGATAAAAAGAAACTCTTGACCCATCAGGGAGAAAGTAT

TGAAAATCGTTTCATCAAAGAGGGTAATCAGCTACCCGATG

AGTTTGTTGTTATCGATCTATATTTCGAGTGTTGCTTATGGG

CGCCAAGTCTATCTCAAGTTGGAAACCACGAGTAAGAGTGA

TGACTGTAGATTCTGCGATTGAAGC

answer.text: Fwd primer 5’GGATCCATGGCATATAGAGCAGTACATG3’ Rev Primer 5’GGTACCGCTTCAATCGCAGAATCTACAG3’
Fwd Primer 5’GGATCCATGGCATATAGAGCAGTACATG3’ Rev Primer 5’CCTAGGGCTTCAATCGCAGAATCTACAG3’
Fwd Primer 5’GCAGGATCCATGGCATATAGAGCAGTACATG3’ Rev Primer 5’GCAGGTACCGCTTCAATCGCAGAATCTACAG3’
Fwd primer 5’GCAGGATCCATGGCATATAGAGCAGTACATG3’ Rev Primer 5’GCTTCAATCGCAGAATCTACAGGCAGGTACC3’
Fwd Primer 5’GCAGGATCCATGGCATATAGAGCAGTACATG3’ Rev Primer 5’GACATCTAAGACGTAACTTCGCCATGGACG3’

questiontext.text: You want to make a 2% (w/v) agarose gel. How much agarose (in grams) do you need to make up a 25 ml gel solution?

answer.text: 5 g

questiontext.text: The steps of conventional PCR are in the following order

answer.text: Denature, anneal, & strand displacement
Denature, anneal and extension
Anneal, denature and extension
Reverse-transcription, anneal and extension
Strand displacement, anneal and extension

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding annealing temperature?

answer.text: Annealing temperature depends on the length and the composition of primer.
If the annealing temperature is low, primers will bind non specifically.
Non-specific binding that occurs at the 5′ end of the primer does not necessarily adversely impact amplification since polymerases cannot begin elongation until the 3′ end binds to the template.
Use of correct annealing temperature in the PCR usually results in optimal PCR product yield with minimum false product production.
Annealing temperature 15°C above the Tm should produce a PCR product, as the likelihood of primer annealing remains unaffected.

questiontext.text: The length of forward and reverse primers must always be equal for a successful PCR reaction

answer.text: true
false
